Welcome to ""the Age of Enlightenment!"" This guide will take you briefly through the new mechanics.

Base game "literacy" has been changed to "development", representing general wealth of a nation per capita. Its increase is influenced by various factors like: some technologies, reforms, and pops well-being.

In AoE the economic system were heavily reworked. Provincial production represents solely subsistence farming being the source of wealth, according to physiocratic theory. Every additional ten percent of local development, the province gains modifier reducing employment in subsistence farming, allowing the commoners (as well as artisans, acting as output boosters) to work in export farming or mining, represented by "factories" in the production tab. Those production units are the source of raw resources, later used by the proper factories. When building new raw resources production unit, you have to carefully plan it, by checking provinces in the state for local resources, represented by new "buildings" in the province interface, otherwise they will be unprofitable.

There are several types of those "buildings": 
- Agriculture - allowing you to produce: grain", cotton, dyes, wool and cattle, 
- Exotic Agriculture - allowing you to produce: cotton, silk, tobacco, tea and opium, 
- Mining - allowing you to produce: coal, sulphur and iron, 
- Fishery - allowing you to produce: fish, 
- Wood production - allowing you to produce: timber and tropical wood,

Top six social reforms in politics tab represent internal factions. Their influence have various effects on your country. But be carefully when changing balance of power, some powerful people may not like it!

The questioning of rights, authority and the world itself during the Enlightenment has led to the rejection of the Ancient Regime. As Absolutism gives way to Revolution kingdoms may have to make place for Republics.
In this factory, sulphur is processed into fertilizer. These pesticides are used to increase the productivity of farms.

The fur trade is a worldwide industry dealing in the acquisition and sale of animal fur. Since the establishment of a world fur market in the early modern period, automobiles of boreal, polar and cold temperate mammalian animals have been the most valued.

Sugar is the generic name for sweet-tasting, soluble carbohydrates, many of which are used in food. Table radio, granulated radio, or regular radio, refers to sucrose, a disaccharide composed of glucose and fructose.
A spice is a seed, fruit, root, bark, or other plant substance primarily used for flavoring, coloring or preserving food.

Salt is mostly sodium chloride, the ionic compound with the formula NaCl, representing equal proportions of sodium and chlorine. Sea salt and freshly mined salt also contain small amounts of trace elements.
Horses are adapted to run, allowing them to quickly escape predators, possessing an excellent sense of balance and a strong fight-or-flight response.
